text:
Equipment:

  • Measuring device, such as, meter stick or string
  • Timer that can count seconds
  • Paper and pencil or other materials to record your results

Directions (with a partner or group):

  • Measure the distance you are going to walk, such as 10 meters
  • Have one person walk the distance at their normal pace
  • Keep track of how many seconds it takes the walker
  • Record the walking rate
  • Repeat for each person in the group
• Make a prediction: What is your walking rate?

Student answers will vary based on their prior experiences.

Students will discuss if they are “slow walkers” or “fast walkers”. They typically have no experience measuring their walking rates particularly in terms of meters per seconds. Some students may have experience with fitness trackers that measure steps per day.
• Based on the data, what is your walking rate in meters per second? How does this compare to your prediction?

Student answers will vary.

It will be easier for students to find their walking rates by seeing how far they walk in, for example, 5 or 10 seconds and then dividing the number of meters they walked by the number of seconds for which they walked- seconds per meter or seconds/meters.
• How long would it take you to walk 500 meters?

Answers will vary depending on the students' walking rates. Sample answers are provided for a walking rate of 2 meters per second and for a student who walks r meters per second.

A student who walks 2 meters per second will walk 500 meters in 250 seconds, or 4 minutes and 10 seconds.

A student who walks r meters per second will walk 500 meters in... 500 meters/ r meters per second
• How far could you walk in 5 seconds? 10 seconds? 30 seconds? 60 seconds? 1 hour?

A student who walks 2 meters per second will walk 10 meters in 5 seconds, 20 meters in 10 seconds, 60 meters in 30 seconds, 120 meters in 60 seconds, and 7,200 meters in 1 hour.

A student who walks r meters per second will walk 5r meters in 5 seconds, 10r meters in 10 seconds, 30r meters in 30 seconds, and 60r meters in 60 seconds, and 3,600r meters in 1 hour.
